basics.description: **Note:** Please refer to the following before installing the solution: • Review the solution [Release Notes](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/tree/master/Solutions/AzureDevOpsAuditing/ReleaseNotes.md) • There may be [known issues](https://aka.ms/sentinelsolutionsknownissues) pertaining to this Solution, please refer to them before installing. The [Azure DevOps](https://azure.microsoft.com/products/devops/) Auditing solution for Microsoft Sentinel allows monitoring Azure DevOps [audit events](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/devops/organizations/audit/azure-devops-auditing?view=azure-devops&tabs=preview-page#review-audit-log) to enable detection of malicious and/or unauthorized access and modification in the repository or pipelines. The streaming of [Azure DevOps Audit logs to Azure Monitor](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/devops/organizations/audit/auditing-streaming?view=azure-devops) must be configured to start ingesting audit events. **Analytic Rules:** 19, **Hunting Queries:** 17 [Learn more about Microsoft Sentinel](https://aka.ms/azuresentinel) | [Learn more about Solutions](https://aka.ms/azuresentinelsolutionsdoc)

options.text: This solution installs the following analytic rule templates. After installing the solution, create and enable analytic rules in Manage solution view.

elements.name: analytic1
elements.label: Azure DevOps Agent Pool Created Then Deleted

options.text:
As well as adding build agents to an existing pool to execute malicious activity within a pipeline, an attacker could create a complete new agent pool and use this for execution.
Azure DevOps allows for the creation of agent pools with Azure hosted infrastructure or self-hosted infrastructure. Given the additional customizability of self-hosted agents this 
detection focuses on the creation of new self-hosted pools. To further reduce false positive rates the detection looks for pools created and deleted relatively quickly (within 7 days by default), 
as an attacker is likely to remove a malicious pool once used in order to reduce/remove evidence of their activity.

elements.name: analytic2
elements.label: Azure DevOps Audit Stream Disabled

options.text:
Azure DevOps allow for audit logs to be streamed to external storage solutions such as SIEM solutions. An attacker looking to hide malicious Azure DevOps activity from defenders may look to disable data streams 
before conducting activity and then re-enabling the stream after (so as not to raise data threshold-based alarms). Looking for disabled audit streams can identify this activity, and due to the nature of the action 
its unlikely to have a high false positive rate.

elements.name: analytic3
elements.label: Azure DevOps Audit Detection for known malicious tooling

options.text: Azure DevOps has been targeted over the years with a handful of toolkits.  This detection will look for some common signs known for a few of these tools.

elements.name: analytic4
elements.label: Azure DevOps New Extension Added

options.text:
Extensions add additional features to Azure DevOps. An attacker could use a malicious extension to conduct malicious activity. 
This query looks for new extensions that are not from a configurable list of approved publishers.

elements.name: analytic5
elements.label: Azure DevOps PAT used with Browser

options.text:
Personal Access Tokens (PATs) are used as an alternate password to authenticate into Azure DevOps. PATs are intended for programmatic access use in code or applications. 
This can be prone to attacker theft if not adequately secured. This query looks for the use of a PAT in authentication but from a User Agent indicating a browser. 
This should not be normal activity and could be an indicator of an attacker using a stolen PAT.

elements.name: analytic6
elements.label: Azure DevOps Pipeline modified by a new user

options.text:
There are several potential pipeline steps that could be modified by an attacker to inject malicious code into the build cycle. A likely attacker path is the modification to an existing pipeline that they have access to. 
This detection looks for users modifying a pipeline when they have not previously been observed modifying or creating that pipeline before. This query also joins events with data to Microsoft Entra ID Protection 
in order to show if the user conducting the action has any associated Microsoft Entra ID Protection alerts. You can also choose to filter this detection to only alert when the user also has Microsoft Entra ID Protection alerts associated with them.

elements.name: analytic7
elements.label: Azure DevOps Retention Reduced

options.text:
AzureDevOps retains items such as run records and produced artifacts for a configurable amount of time. An attacker looking to reduce the footprint left by their malicious activity may look to reduce the retention time for artifacts and runs.
This query will look for where retention has been reduced to the minimum level - 1, or reduced by more than half.

elements.name: analytic8
elements.label: Azure DevOps Variable Secret Not Secured

options.text:
Credentials used in the build process may be stored as Azure DevOps variables. To secure these variables they should be stored in KeyVault or marked as Secrets. 
This detection looks for new variables added with names that suggest they are credentials but where they are not set as Secrets or stored in KeyVault.

elements.name: analytic9
elements.label: Azure DevOps Build Variable Modified by New User

options.text:
Variables can be configured and used at any stage of the build process in Azure DevOps to inject values. An attacker with the required permissions could modify 
or add to these variables to conduct malicious activity such as changing paths or remote endpoints called during the build. As variables are often changed by users, 
just detecting these changes would have a high false positive rate. This detection looks for modifications to variable groups where that user has not been observed 
modifying them before.

elements.name: analytic10
elements.label: Azure DevOps Administrator Group Monitoring

options.text: This detection monitors for additions to projects or project collection administration groups in an Azure DevOps Organization.

elements.name: analytic11
elements.label: Azure DevOps Pull Request Policy Bypassing - Historic allow list

options.text: This detection builds an allow list of historic PR policy bypasses and compares to recent history, flagging pull request bypasses that are not manually in the allow list and not historically included in the allow list.

elements.name: analytic12
elements.label: Azure DevOps Service Connection Addition/Abuse - Historic allow list

options.text:
This detection builds an allow list of historic service connection use by Builds and Releases and compares to recent history, flagging growth of service connection use which are not manually included in the allow list and
not historically included in the allow list Build/Release runs.  This is to determine if someone is hijacking a build/release and adding many service connections in order to abuse or dump credentials from service connections.

elements.name: analytic13
elements.label: Azure DevOps Personal Access Token (PAT) misuse

options.text:
This Alert detects whenever a PAT is used in ways that PATs are not normally used. May require an allow list and baselining.
Reference - https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/devops/organizations/accounts/use-personal-access-tokens-to-authenticate?view=azure-devops&tabs=preview-page
Use this query for baselining:
AzureDevOpsAuditing
| distinct OperationName

elements.name: analytic14
elements.label: Azure DevOps Pipeline Created and Deleted on the Same Day

options.text:
An attacker with access to Azure DevOps could create a pipeline to inject artifacts used by other pipelines, 
or to create a malicious software build that looks legitimate by using a pipeline that incorporates legitimate elements. 
An attacker would also likely want to cover their tracks once conducting such activity. This query looks for Pipelines 
created and deleted within the same day, this is unlikely to be legitimate user activity in the majority of cases.

elements.name: analytic15
elements.label: Azure DevOps Service Connection Abuse

options.text:
Flags builds/releases that use a large number of service connections if they aren't manually in the allow list.
This is to determine if someone is hijacking a build/release and adding many service connections in order to abuse
or dump credentials from service connections.

elements.name: analytic16
elements.label: External Upstream Source Added to Azure DevOps Feed

options.text:
The detection looks for new external sources added to an Azure DevOps feed. An allow list can be customized to explicitly allow known good sources. 
An attacker could look to add a malicious feed in order to inject malicious packages into a build pipeline.

elements.name: analytic17
elements.label: New Agent Added to Pool by New User or Added to a New OS Type

options.text:
As seen in attacks such as SolarWinds attackers can look to subvert a build process by controlling build servers. Azure DevOps uses agent pools to execute pipeline tasks. 
An attacker could insert compromised agents that they control into the pools in order to execute malicious code. This query looks for users adding agents to pools they have 
not added agents to before, or adding agents to a pool of an OS that has not been added to that pool before. This detection has potential for false positives so has a 
configurable allow list to allow for certain users to be excluded from the logic.

elements.name: analytic18
elements.label: New PA, PCA, or PCAS added to Azure DevOps

options.text:
In order for an attacker to be able to conduct many potential attacks against Azure DevOps they will need to gain elevated permissions. 
This detection looks for users being granted key administrative permissions. If the principal of least privilege is applied, the number of 
users granted these permissions should be small. Note that permissions can also be granted via Microsoft Entra ID Protection groups and monitoring of these 
should also be conducted.

elements.name: analytic19
elements.label: NRT Azure DevOps Audit Stream Disabled

options.text:
Azure DevOps allow for audit logs to be streamed to external storage solutions such as SIEM solutions. An attacker looking to hide malicious Azure DevOps activity from defenders may look to disable data streams 
 before conducting activity and then re-enabling the stream after (so as not to raise data threshold-based alarms). Looking for disabled audit streams can identify this activity, and due to the nature of the action 
 its unlikely to have a high false positive rate.
This solution installs the following hunting queries. After installing the solution, run these hunting queries to hunt for threats in Manage solution view.

elements.name: huntingquery1
elements.label: Azure DevOps- Microsoft Entra ID Protection Conditional Access Disabled

options.text: This hunting query identifies Azure DevOps activities where organization Microsoft Entra ID ConditionalAccess policy disable by the admin This hunting query depends on AzureMonitor data connector (AzureDevOpsAuditing Parser or Table)

elements.name: huntingquery2
elements.label: Azure DevOps- Addtional Org Admin added

options.text: This hunting query identifies Azure DevOps activities where additional organization admin is added This hunting query depends on AzureMonitor data connector (AzureDevOpsAuditing Parser or Table)

elements.name: huntingquery3
elements.label: Azure DevOps - Build Check Deleted

options.text: This query searches for removal of build checks from the Azure DevOps pipeline. Removal of build checks are rare and may be indication of build pipeline compromise.

elements.name: huntingquery4
elements.label: Azure DevOps - Build Deleted After Pipeline Modification

options.text: Attackers may delete builds after modifying pipelines to minimize traces. This query spots such deletions within an hour of pipeline changes, aiding in system footprint reduction.

elements.name: huntingquery5
elements.label: Azure DevOps - Internal Upstream Package Feed Added

options.text: Attackers may introduce upstream packages into the build process to insert malicious code. This query searches for such malicious activity. If an environment has low number of events, it can be upgraded to a detection.

elements.name: huntingquery6
elements.label: Azure DevOps - New Agent Pool Created

options.text: Compromised agent pools in pipelines can allow build process breaches. While creating agent pools isn't inherently malicious, their infrequent creation makes them notable for Azure DevOps monitoring.

elements.name: huntingquery7
elements.label: Azure DevOps - New Package Feed Created

options.text: This query identifies users who created new package feed to Azure DevOps pipelines, having no prior history of feed creation, suggesting possible unauthorized activity and requiring verification.

elements.name: huntingquery8
elements.label: Azure DevOps - New PAT Operation

options.text: Using PATs for new operations may signal misuse. This query flags unfamiliar PAT-based operations, potentially indicating malicious use of a stolen PAT.

elements.name: huntingquery9
elements.label: Azure DevOps - New Release Approver

options.text: Release approvals in Azure Pipelines, often user-authorized, can be self-approved by attackers using compromised accounts. This query identifies unusual approvers, aiding in the detection of unauthorized releases.

elements.name: huntingquery10
elements.label: Azure DevOps - New Release Pipeline Created

options.text: This query identifies users who created new package feed to Azure DevOps pipelines, having no prior history of feed creation, suggesting possible unauthorized activity and requiring verification.

elements.name: huntingquery11
elements.label: Azure DevOps - Variable Created and Deleted

options.text: The query detects additions and removals of variables in build processes in a short span of time, possibly indicating malicious activity. Promoting to a detection if few such events occur.

elements.name: huntingquery12
elements.label: Azure DevOps Display Name Changes

options.text: Shows all users with more than 1 display name in recent history.  This is to hunt for users maliciously changing their display name as a masquerading technique This hunting query depends on AzureMonitor data connector (AzureDevOpsAuditing Parser or Table)

elements.name: huntingquery13
elements.label: Azure DevOps Pull Request Policy Bypassing

options.text: Looks for users bypassing Update Policies in repos This hunting query depends on AzureMonitor data connector (AzureDevOpsAuditing Parser or Table)

elements.name: huntingquery14
elements.label: Azure DevOps- Guest users access enabled

options.text: This hunting query identifies Azure DevOps activities where organization Guest Access policy is enabled by the admin This hunting query depends on AzureMonitor data connector (AzureDevOpsAuditing Parser or Table)

elements.name: huntingquery15
elements.label: Azure DevOps- Project visibility changed to public

options.text: This hunting query identifies Azure DevOps activities where organization project visibility changed to public project This hunting query depends on AzureMonitor data connector (AzureDevOpsAuditing Parser or Table)

elements.name: huntingquery16
elements.label: Azure DevOps- Public project created

options.text: This hunting query identifies Azure DevOps activities where a public project is created This hunting query depends on AzureMonitor data connector (AzureDevOpsAuditing Parser or Table)

elements.name: huntingquery17
elements.label: Azure DevOps- Public project enabled by admin

options.text: This hunting query identifies Azure DevOps activities where organization public projects policy enabled by the admin This hunting query depends on AzureMonitor data connector (AzureDevOpsAuditing Parser or Table)
